awd_titl_txt: SG RUI: Snow melt-induced changes in phenology as direct and indirect drivers of herbivore abundance
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants are abundant and widely distributed on earth, despite the fact that many different species of animals feed on them, i.e., herbivores.  The world remains green with plants because a variety of factors limit the intensity of herbivory.  Understanding these limiting factors is an important goal of ecology.  This research focuses on how the seasonal timing of interactions between plants and herbivorous insects could limit herbivory. The project examines interactions between plants and their herbivorous aphids, which form vast colonies on the flowering stalks of the plants, making them an ideal study system for experimental manipulation. The aphid colonies interact with other insects, including ants that provide them with protection from predators. Six years of data show that when snow melts earlier in spring, host plants flower earlier, and this earlier flowering tends to be associated with an increase in aphid numbers.  To understand what is causing this association, the researchers will experimentally alter snow cover as a way to vary the timing of plant-insect interactions.  This work is important because it adds to our understanding of how changes in the timing of when organisms interact with each other, affect food webs, and the resulting ecological communities. The results will have implications for predicting the abundance of insect herbivores in natural and agricultural systems affected by an earlier arrival of spring. This project will also provide undergraduate students from under-served communities with training in field ecology, and will develop learning opportunities for K-12 teachers and students.

Using a combination of observational and experimental approaches, this research will determine the direct and indirect effects of changes in plant phenology on herbivore abundance.  In this study system, aphids (Aphis helianthi) colonize the inflorescences of their host plant (Ligusticum porteri), and six years of monitoring indicates that advances in host-plant phenology (earlier flowering) are associated with increases in the abundance of aphids. This correlation between plant phenology and the abundance of herbivores may be due to the direct effects of phenology on plant nutritional quality and/or to the indirect mediation of interactions among ants, predators and competitors. This study will apply a structural equation modeling approach to evaluate hypotheses about how phenological cues influence arthropod abundance through these direct and indirect trophic interactions. The study will directly vary host plant phenology through the experimental manipulation of snow melt using plant populations found along an elevational gradient. These experiments will also employ a factorial design to combine plant phenology treatments with treatments that alter the accessibility of aphid colonies to their mutualists and/or predators.  Differences in aphid colony growth among treatments will show the relative magnitudes of direct and indirect effects of plant stage.  Laboratory assays of phloem sap and aphid quality (e.g., C/N ratio, secondary metabolite content etc.) will complement these field experiments and provide a mechanism by which host plant phenology could affect aphid population growth or the ant-aphid mutualism.

por.por_cntn:
Winter is changing. Most notably, snow is melting earlier in the year, revealing bare ground, and initiating spring. This change can reshape the ecological communities tied to human well-being. In this project, we determined how snowmelt timing affects herbivore abundance for a study system consisting of a host plant, an aphid herbivore, and the arthropods that interact with aphids, including predators and mutualists. This aphid species (Aphis asclepias) colonizes host plant flowering stalks in June through August. The flowering stalks are a rich food source for sap feeding aphids. Aphid colonies rapidly grow as each individual can clones themselves through live birth. Aphids have a mutually beneficial relationship with ants (Figure 1). Ants protect aphids from predators, and in exchange, aphids produce a sugar-rich excretion known as honeydew. The colonies replicate themselves by producing winged migrants known as alates. Through multiple years of counting insects on plants, we found that years with early snowmelt years are associated with few aphid colonies. Our research sought to determine the mechanisms behind this association. Simply put, we answered the question: why do aphids care about snow? Like most other phenomena in nature, many threads weave the connection between snow and aphid abundance. To understand these connections, we formed scientific team of diverse researchers: students, analytical chemists, plant physiologists, and K-12 teachers. In forming this team, we recruited undergraduate researchers from groups underrepresented in the sciences. Also, we added to the growing strength of the graduate research program at the University of Colorado Colorado Springs.

We found that early loss of snow drives changes in host plants, mutualists, and predators. Our first set of experiments focused on the impacts of early snowmelt for soil moisture. In our subalpine area, soils dry when snow melts early in the season, well before the arrival of summer monsoonal rains. In a field experiment, we added either snow in May or water in June through July to replicate host plant plots. Then, we compared multispecies interactions under these host plant treatments to those under ambient dry conditions. Dry conditions cascade through our study system leading to drought stressed host plants, smaller aphid colonies, and altered interactions with ants. In this study year, we found that ant presence on aphid colonies reduced their growth. Given the overall dry conditions, ants from beyond the study plots were likely raiding aphid colonies as predators. When ants were excluded, we observed clear differences in host plant quality. Aphid colonies grew the most on host plants that had received snow in May relative to either those with water in June-July or under the ambient dry conditions.  Snow is essential to create host plants that sustain aphid populations.

Our second set of experiments examined the role of predators. In this system, the major predator of aphids are insects known as mirids, chiefly those belonging to the Lygus genus. Mirids use their piercing-sucking mouthparts to both eat plant tissues and soft bodied insects. From observations of 20 host plant populations, we show that earlier loss of snow is associated with a greater abundance of mirids in June. Mirids overwinter as adults in dried plant material, so early loss of snow gives these insects a boost in spring. We assessed their direct and indirect impacts on aphid abundance. Mirid feeding notoriously damage plants, leading to their common names as tarnished plant bugs. We how changes initiated by mirid feeding could affect aphid host plant choice. Winged aphids use visual, olfactory, and other cues to select their hosts. We focused on scent compounds released by plants known as volatiles. We added mirids to host plant flowering stalks and kept another set mirid-free as controls. Mirids fed freely from the host plants for several weeks. After this time, we removed the mirids and captured volatiles using scent traps. These scent traps work by using a small air pump to pull air samples through a highly absorbent material, which can then be analyzed with a sensitive instrument. We found that mirid feeding changes the volatile bouquet release by host plants. When winged aphids were given a choice, they selected mirid-free control plants by a margin of four to one compared to those that had prior mirid feeding. Mirids are not merely a threat at aphid colony initiation. Their populations ramp up throughout the season. REU student Emily Cruz focused on how predation by mirid would impact aphid colonies, even when they were tended by ants. She found dramatic reductions in aphid colony growth and the production of winged migrants when mirids were present.
